Mar 29

Inside the Brooklyn Nets‚Äô March¬†Mania

The Brooklyn Nets have had a solid March, improving in nearly every statistical category. What‚Äôs been the driving force in their late season turnaround?

As of late, the Brooklyn Nets have been surprisingly‚Ä¶ solid. After their game against the Philadelphia 76ers on Tuesday, the Nets hold a 7‚Äì9 record in March. I know. 7‚Äì9 may not be the most impressive record. If the Cavaliers went 7‚Äì9, the various basketball media talking heads would have a field day.

Wait. That‚Äôs happening already.

But for the Nets, a 7‚Äì9 record is noteworthy. From December to February, Brooklyn went 4‚Äì36. And despite the turnaround, they still own the worst record in the NBA by a decent margin. Hey, it‚Äôs a start!

Yes, the Nets‚Äô March victories include wins against some subpar teams. The Kings, Knicks, Suns, and the Paul Millsap-less Hawks aren‚Äôt exactly Batman‚Äôs Rogues Gallery of opponents. But it‚Äôs an improvement for a team that has struggled mightily. For first-year Head Coach Kenny Atkinson, it shows that despite the team‚Äôs struggles, the Nets fight every night.

The Brooklyn Nets Will Eventually Creep Out Of Gloomy Era
Remnants of the Billy King era certainly remain, but Sean Marks is the perfect executive to take the Nets out of this‚Ä¶16winsaring.com

What‚Äôs Different?

Offensively, the team still follows the same principles‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääshoot threes, push the pace and attack. The team‚Äôs pace has remained lightning-quick, ranking in the top five in the league both in March and prior to that. Defensively, the Nets‚Äô rotations are still super fluid, switching on everything not involving Brook Lopez. The philosophies remain the same, yet the metrics show notable improvement.

In their first 58 games, the 9‚Äì49 Nets ranked 24th and 25th in field goal percentage and three-point field goal percentage respectively, per NBA.com/stats. Since the turn of the month, the Nets rank 17th and 12th in those categories. Those number rank higher than playoff teams like the Memphis Grizzlies, Utah Jazz and Boston Celtics. The team has also jumped defensively, going from 27th to 13th in defensive rating. One major area the Nets have struggled in‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääon both ends‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääis rebounding. They have rebounded well lately, ranking 18th in rebounding percentage this month, compared to 27th prior to March 1.

All those numbers look great! Case closed. Let‚Äôs end the article now, thanks for reading! But actually, let‚Äôs break it down like D-Generation X. (Sorry, it‚Äôs Wrestlemania week).

What has driven the Nets to respectability this March?

4-on-4: Sixteen Roundtable
Four staff members from 16 Wins A Ring answering four NBA related questions‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwelcome to the Sixteen Roundtable.16winsaring.com

Premier Athletes

When the Nets traded Bojan Bogdanovic to the Washington Wizards, they dealt their second-leading scorer for a first-round draft pick. While Bojan‚Äôs scoring touch is missed, the athleticism of his replacements has allowed the Nets to push the pace offensively and compete defensively.

The Nets‚Äô backcourt youth is impressive for a team devoid of assets. Caris LeVert, Isaiah Whitehead, K.J. McDaniels, Spencer Dinwiddie and Archie Goodwin are all under 24, and aim to be contributors in the Nets‚Äô future. All five wings possess above-average athleticism or length, a trait that General Manager Sean Marks emphasizes.

The Nets, infamously, passed on Yogi Ferrell, a small but active playmaker. Ferrell‚Äôs replacements: Isaiah Whitehead and Spencer Dinwiddie, have capitalized on their length and athleticism on both ends. Here, Dinwiddie uses his length (6-foot-8 wingspan and 8-foot-7 standing reach) to intercept a pass and spark the fast break.

Whitehead, a rookie combo guard, has generated highlights on both ends this month. Offensively, his patented ‚ÄúCyclone‚Äù spin has been the subject of Twitter compilations and a dank meme. Defensively, he uses his length to contest closeouts and his bounce to scurry and block shots in the paint.

Z-Bo didn‚Äôt see Whitehead coming. Even on switches, Whitehead holds his own. In the Nets‚Äô March 12 victory against the New York Knicks, the 6-foot-4 Whitehead was able to push Carmelo Anthony out of the post and contest his iso-ball shots.

The two newest Nets, K.J. McDaniels and Archie Goodwin, are two wings who struggled to find success in previous stops. But, they have found new life in Brooklyn this month.

McDaniels has made his mark after years of dormancy‚Ää‚Äî‚Äälike Missy Elliott at the Super Bowl XLIX halftime show. He has averaged 13 minutes per game as a Nets reserve. McDaniels is an ideal fast break player, a bouncy speed demon for the post-Vine era. He is still raw offensively, but his effort makes up for a lack of polish. Watch him go full Superman against the Jazz. Then look at the score. Dude.

He shows his greatest potential defensively. McDaniels possesses solid defensive instincts, moving well laterally, using his athletic gifts to stymie offensive players. Here, McDaniels pulls a Dikembe Mutombo on a Dwight Howard layup attempt.

Archie Goodwin is on his second 10-day contract, but he has contributed to the Nets‚Äô recent success, averaging 7.6 points in five games. Coach Kenny Atkinson sees Goodwin as a natural point guard, with a propensity to create and attack with the ball. His 6-foot-10 wingspan allows him to guard multiple positions (hmmm‚Ä¶I see a trend) and his athleticism makes him an unlikely, but welcome point guard option.

The Nets‚Äô young crown jewel is Caris LeVert. After a Joe Harris injury against the Utah Jazz on March 3, LeVert was inserted into the starting lineup. He‚Äôs made his mark. While he hasn‚Äôt had explosive scoring performances, LeVert has been solid all around. Defensively, he looks like a safety returning an interception after a steal.

LeVert is a more complete offensive product compared to his fellow wings. He can attack off the dribble and shoot from deep. He is adept at passing off of penetration, able to find shooters and big men in the paint. Defensively, LeVert has been switched onto point guards and power forwards and held his own. Even if LeVert doesn‚Äôt pan out, he at least has one fan.

The injection of athleticism into Brooklyn‚Äôs rotation has allowed the Nets to attack off the bounce and push the pace. Defensively, the team‚Äôs newfound length creates opponent matchup nightmares.

Trade Grades: Bojan Bojan Bojan, Wizards Up to Something
TRADE GRADES: Bojan Bogdanovic and Chris McCullough for Andrew Nicholson, Marcus Thornton and 2017 Wizards First-Round‚Ä¶16winsaring.com

The Power Forward¬†Project

Trevor Booker seems like the perfect fit next to Brook Lopez. Booker is an athletic, all-effort power forward that can gobble rebounds on both ends. It‚Äôs like the Kris Humphries-Brook Lopez combo all over again! If I‚Äôm the only one who gets nostalgic when thinking of those two, sorry.

The Booker-Lopez starting frontcourt may have hindered the Nets‚Äô success. Coach Kenny Atkinson shook up the lineup on February 1, swapping Booker for Rondae Hollis-Jefferson, a 6-foot-7 wing. Hollis-Jefferson is slowly adjusting to moving to the four and seems to have found his niche.

RHJ, while still not a perimeter threat, is a ball of frenzied energy on both ends of the court. His wild drives to the rim keep defenses on their heels, even on weird herky-jerky double-pump layups. Take a look.

He draws fouls at a higher clip than Booker,¬†.429 to¬†.198, in part to his drives. Defensively, Hollis-Jefferson is a bit more adept at playing switches. A small forward for most of his career, RHJ is comfortable guarding on the perimeter.

A move to the bench isn‚Äôt all bad for Booker. In the Nets‚Äô second unit, Booker has slid over to the center spot, often playing alongside Quincy Acy as a reserve. Acy has transformed into a three-point threat. His 47.2 percent (not a typo) clip from three has lifted the second unit. Booker is more comfortable being the Nets‚Äô second unit post player, where he can post smaller opponents up, or grab offensive boards. The Nets‚Äô offense primarily features a 4-out, 1-in configuration. Brook Lopez is the de-facto post player for the Nets‚Äô starting five, leaving Booker, neither a drive nor shooting threat, on the perimeter.

The numbers show a team-wide benefit. The Nets‚Äô true shooting percentage with Lopez and Hollis-Jefferson is 57.5 percent, while the Lopez-Booker tandem shot 55.6 percent. Further, the Acy-Booker bench combo holds a net rating of 5.7 in 159 minutes. In comparison, Lopez and Booker held a -6.9 net rating, while the RHJ-Lopez two-man lineup has a net rating of 0.4. Hollis-Jefferson may have defensive lapses against bigger power forwards, but his energy has provided a needed boost for a struggling Nets starting lineup. In March, the Nets have gone smaller‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand have thrived with it.

Can the Pelicans make another miraculous playoff run?
The Pelicans made a miraculous playoff run back in 2015. Can they do it again in 2017?16winsaring.com

Jeremy Lin

This is the part everyone‚Äôs been waiting for, right? So here‚Äôs some lyrics that need #views

That‚Äôs why I need a¬†J-Lin
Got the basketball in his¬†hands,
One more win this year,¬†oh
Lopez PNR got a hold on¬†me

Lin‚Äôs return has revitalized the Nets. That‚Äôs obvious. After missing over half of the season due to recurring hamstring issues, Lin has lifted the Nets post-All-Star Break and into March. The presence of a veteran point guard does wonders for a team on both ends of the court. That‚Äôs evident through their record in March. We know Lin excels at the high pick-and-roll and through dribble penetration. He‚Äôs brought those skills to the Nets.

Lin has become the primary ball-handler for the Nets, whereas in previous stops, he played alongside ball magnets Kemba Walker and James Harden. Lin‚Äôs mastery of the little things has allowed the Nets to sustain their pace and run their offense fruitfully. One understated aspect of Lin‚Äôs return is his ability to push it real good. That‚Äôs evident in his outlet passes, which capitalize on his teammates‚Äô athleticism.

He may not be Timberwolves-era Kevin Love, but Lin‚Äôs vision generates easy looks for his teammates in transition. He may average only 4.4 assists per game in March (and 7.2 potential assists per game), but his ability to set his teammates up for easy buckets was missed for a majority of the season.

Most hoops fans have read the stories or watched the Netflix Linsanity documentary. That was five years ago (whoa). But, Lin is still an effective‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand dramatic closer.

The Nets have been able to stay in games throughout the season‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa testament to the effort of their players. However, they struggled closing out games, entering scoring droughts that eventually doom them. Lin has righted the ship for the Nets in the fourth. He has shot 66.7 percent from the field in clutch situations in March, with a straight up Christopher Bridges net rating of 41.4 in five clutch games. Here‚Äôs another one of his #daggers that led to Nets wins‚Ä¶

That also doesn‚Äôt mention Lin‚Äôs effectiveness with Brook Lopez. With a pun name as clever as Brook-Lin, there was no way that tandem wouldn‚Äôt have been successful. In his games with the Nets, Lin has shown what the team could have been if he were healthy all year. It‚Äôs the life of a Nets fan.

The Clippers Have A Blake Griffin Dilemma
Blake Griffin‚Äôs future in LA is something of a question. It‚Äôs time to stick or twist for the Clippers with their star‚Ä¶16winsaring.com

#EmbraceTheFuture

Here‚Äôs my reaction when reflecting on the Nets‚Äô March. While their 7‚Äì9 March record may not be super impressive, the team seems to be on the right track. The team‚Äôs athleticism and fluidity has become more evident‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa model for the team‚Äôs fast-paced future.

With few games left for the Nets, it‚Äôs all about respectability. If they play well, they could surpass the Lakers and Suns in the win-loss column. But even if that isn‚Äôt achieved, a spirited run at the end of the season bodes well for the success of the team. The Nets don‚Äôt have their first-round draft picks for the next two seasons. Fans know. General Manager Sean Marks emphasized daily improvement for the Nets at the beginning of this season. The Nets‚Äô March improvement has shown that‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäThis. Is. Progress.

PS‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäHere‚Äôs a Brook Lopez game-winner if you weren‚Äôt convinced that the Nets could be the feel good story of the next few NBA seasons‚Ä¶
